review.title: A system of serial computation for classified rules prediction in non-regular ontology trees
review.abstract: Objects or structures that are regular take uniform dimensions. Based on the concepts of regular models, our previous research work has developed a system of a regular ontology that models learning structures in a multiagent system for uniform pre-assessments in a learning environment. This regular ontology has led to the modelling of a classified rules learning algorithm that predicts the actual number of rules needed for inductive learning processes and decision making in a multiagent system. But not all processes or models are regular. Thus this paper presents a system of polynomial equation that can estimate and predict the required number of rules of a non-regular ontology model given some defined parameters.
histories: 13 pages, 15 figures, International Journal article, PhD research work
review.COMMENTS: 13 pages, 15 figures, International Journal article, PhD research work

metadata.title: A SYSTEM OF SERIAL COMPUTATION FOR CLASSIFIED RULES PREDICTION IN NON- REGULAR ONTOLOGY TREES

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijaia.2016.7202 21Regular objects or structures assume uniform dimensions. Based on the concepts of regular models, our previous research has developed a system of regular ontology that models learning structures in a multi-agent system for uniform pre-assessments in a learning environment. This regular ontology has led to the modelling of a classified regulator algorithm that predicts the actual number of rules required for inductive learning processes and decision-making in a multi-agent system. However, not all processes or models are regular. Therefore, this paper presents a system of polynomial equations that can estimate and predict the required number of rules of an irregular ontology model taking into account certain parameters. KEYWORDSMultiagent, Classification Learning, Predictive Modelling, Polynomia, Coercision, Ontology Tree, Boolean, Students, Artificial Intelligence

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: This section describes descriptive work on classification learning using Boolean value parameters and predictive models for learning probabilistic uncertainties related to semantic networks.

sections.heading: 2.1 Reasoning in Semantic Nets and Recommender Systems
sections.text: Different calculation techniques exist for the conceptual estimation of ontological tree structures. However, learning about probabilistic uncertainties takes different forms. While some stem from the distribution of unclear quantities, others are discrete or continuous Gaussian distributions [11]. From the use of semantic properties and node attributes, semantic recommendation systems have been exploited for the purpose of creating or generating recommendations, because the underlying techniques provide a means of detecting and classifying unknown characteristics or items [32], [31]. Based on semantic networks, some classification or recommendation systems based on user-to-user relationships [1] or / andite-to-item relationships [14] have been built. These are systems where the recommendation process is determined by the evaluation of items - positive or negative - that are used to calculate the similarity between a given group of characteristics based on the Items, calculate the similarity structure of the Items based on a neighborhood of the Items, calculate the similarity structure of the Items based on a neighborhood of the Items.

sections.heading: 2.3 Discrete Parameters and Classification
sections.text: Discrete or Boolean parameters are values that take only two possible values: 1 or 0. In practical systems, this implies: on or off, good or bad, working or notWorking, found or notFound, present or notPresent, etc. Investigating the ontology of the relationship term in [16], [17] for the pre-evaluation of students from node to node in a regular ontology: Ontology with an equal number of leaf nodes across all parent nodes (Fig.1) used the Boolean parameter T = 2 torepresent either as a pass or a fail to measure the results of the pre-evaluation. The parameters T and leaf node N of a given parent class node then formed the basis for learning the agent classification. Classification learning is a trait, instance or attribute learning. sections.heading: 3. RULES ESTIMATION AND PREDICTION IN NON- REGULAR ONTOLOGY TREES
sections.text: In contrast to the concept of regular ontologies, a non-regular ontology tree structure is an ontology with a random structure and an arbitrary number of leaf nodes. How can classified inductive learning rules for non-regular ontologies be estimated and predicted? One of the likely solutions is to take apart each relationship of the parent class and its leaf nodes and treat them as unit components of the sum. In this system of multiagents there is a classification agent. Using the reviewed learning approach, in Figures 4 and 5, we present the input-output-output-output-output-output-knowledge representation of the class.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION AND FURTHER WORK
sections.text: This paper demonstrated the estimation and prediction of the number of classification rules on an irregular ontology structure using a system of polynomial equations, and then the representation of the knowledge of the predicted estimate for classification learning. While the polynomial equation can predict the estimation of the decision rules for both a regular and an irregular ontology, the initialization algorithm only predicts decision rules for regular ontologies. Classification learning is the process of specifying a pair of {X, Y} training examples for a system to be learned so that it can make a selection of unknown inputs based on the given examples. In a student learning environment, this process has been demonstrated with an irregular ontology structure. Inputs for learning agents are the X predicates of logical statements specified in the area of its prerequisites for selectively categorizing any output Y specified in the body of the agent's plans. But it could be awkward to determine the number of knots for a large number of rules.

metadata.abstractText: Objects or structures that are regular take uniform dimensions. Based on the concepts of regular models, our previous research work has developed a system of a regular ontology that models learning structures in a multiagent system for uniform pre-assessments in a learning environment. This regular ontology has led to the modelling of a classified rules learning algorithm that predicts the actual number of rules needed for inductive learning processes and decision making in a multiagent system. But not all processes or models are regular. Thus this paper presents a system of polynomial equation that can estimate and predict the required number of rules of a non-regular ontology model given some defined parameters.
